review_text:
3.5 stars rounded to 4

Every once in awhile I like to dip my toes into a novel channeled through poetry, and this one maintains a nice blend of traditional beauty and modern relevance. While I usually don't embrace stories where a majority of the conflict could have been solved by two characters just having a simple conversation, I do understand that mother/daughter relationships can be very strained and it can be difficult to overcome this bridge. Some heavy themes are discussed here, and there

This was good! A super quick, engaging read that offered a somewhat predictable but still important and enjoyable look at discovering your family heritage isn't what you thought it was — and, more than that, learning that your parents are humans who make terrible mistakes sometimes, and finding how to move past that. I will say that everything felt a little flat overall, which is why this wasn't a 5-star read, but I'm feeling that way about a lot of novels in verse lately, so perhaps my tastes a
Sooo good! I love how this story was written in emails and text messages. Made the reading experience even better.

A seemingly simple senior genealogy project turned into a life altering discovery for eighteen year old Cordelia Koenig. After receiving her DNA results, Cornelia now knew why she always seemed to not quite fit in with the rest of her family. Told through texts, emails, and poetry, Cordelia goes through an emotional journey of self discovery. But during that journey, she became so self absorbed that she neglected and lied to the people who most loved her.

Some parts of this story were a bit frus
3.5 stars will update with a short review super soon!!

I was lucky enough to read an early copy of this incredible book. If you like:

-multimedia storytelling
-sciency girls
-family intrigue, and
-swoony boys...

This book is for you! I can’t wait to show off copies to my students!!!

**June 24th update**
I read this in one day which RARELY happens! This book was so emotional, complicated, sad but also beautiful and a rare gem of a book. I cared for Cordelia so much and I loved seeing her grow and discover herself. Plus a great book with an awesome father figure!! Please please read this when it comes out later this year! ♥️♥️♥️♥️ Review now on the blog

I AM ready for this book! A girl who has a genealogy test done and learns about her re

Lucky me! I also had the privilege of getting my grabby hands on an early copy of The Truth Project. This book, people! You will laugh, cry, pause... sink deep into the heartfelt poetry, and when your finished, wait ever so impatiently to read what's next from Dante Medema.

She had always felt like she didn't fit into her family, but when she received the results from her DNA test, Cordelia now had the proof of why. Discovering her father was not the man who raised her set Cordelia's world off balance and sent her searching for the truth. Of who he was, and also, who she was.

• Pro: My emotions! With the subject matter, there was no doubt I would feel something, but I felt so much as I read this story. It was a tsunami of feelings that washed over me, and it came f

This is an utterly original book. It's completely different from anything I've read before. The writing is lyrical and luminous, the characters feel real, and the themes-- including family, identity, and seeking your truth-- will deeply resonate with readers. I'm so fortunate I was able to read this early! Dante Medema is a writer to watch.

I find novels in verse to be very impactful emotionally, and The Truth Project is no different. It's a heartfelt exploration of family, betrayal, and forgiveness that will hook you from the very first page. I loved seeing Cordelia's emotional journey in her self discovery and realizing what family means to her - while navigating the life changing secrets her mother kept that are now changing her life.

I curled up on the couch and could not put down this book!
Poet Cordelia does a senior project about her family's genealogy and learns that the father who raised her is not her biological father.
Written with poems, emails, texts, and beautiful verse, this is a novel about identity, family, friendship and love. You'll want to read this and every other book Dante Medema writes!

You can find the full review and all the fancy and/or randomness that accompanies it at It Starts at Midnight

This was such a heartfelt, lovely story about what it means to be "family". Told in verse (and some mixed-media), we follow Cordelia, who wants to explore her DNA for a school project (and the sake of curiosity, of course).  And what she thinks will be an easy A brings her both her former friend/crush Kodiak, as well as some deeply distressing news about her parentage. Her father turns o

Trigger warnings: (view spoiler)
Diversity: Half-Asian, lesbian main character, Asian and Indian side characters, main character with Tlingit origins.

What a beautiful book. I fell in love with the words and the story and, even if I'm not used to novels in verse, I found it so easy to be captivated by this one. I loved Cordelia's journey SO much and definitely recommend this book. I can't wait to read more

This book will surprise and delight you, like nothing you've ever read before. I cannot recommend it enough -- I read it in less than a day. Cordelia's story was so believable, and yet it was fresh, new, unique. Love this novel-in-verse, for teens, for adults, for everyone.

review_text:
Beautifully written, with characters so deep you want to dive into them without care for how shallow the water might be.

It doesn’t belong on your bookshelf, if belongs in your desk-open.

Cordelia is embroiled in a crisis when she decides to merge her passion for poetry with her senior project about her heritage. It was going to be a disaster from the start since Cordelia always felt different from the rest of her sisters. And her DNA profile gives her what she suspected: that her dad is not her biological father.

The unfolding includes a small group of Cordelia’s inner circle- her best friend Sana, a lost love Kodiak who had hurt of his own (from the past year of being a bad boy

This book perfectly captures that am-I-adopted? feeling of familial dissonance I remember having so clearly as a teenager. I would have loved this book as a teen--its big emotions, its characters trying to figure out who they are and what they want and making mistakes along the way.

I was surprised to find that a novel mostly in verse could be so gripping--Medema's plot is as well-developed as her beautiful language. I read the whole thing in just a few sittings and finished it with tears in my
GIVE IT TO ME. NOW.

READ THIS BOOK.

(more full review TC. But honestly, this book is incredible. Read it.)

“At the end of the day, you have to be okay with the you inside your heart.”

This is such a fabulous, tender book about what family is and what it means to belong. Dante Medema explores the emotional fallout & rollercoaster ride of emotions of a teenage girl after she discovers her true parentage. The style is unique and fresh, as it’s told through a series of poems, texts, and emails. It's a contemporary YA coming of age story perfect for fans of Elizabeth Acevedo!

The Truth Project follows seni

To be 100% honest, I do not like Young Adult fiction. But when your good friend gets her debut novel published, you read it to show your support. This book was very true to the nature of Young Adult fiction, but the fact that it was so beautifully told trough a very unusual lens of a series of text messages, emails, and beautiful poetry - well, it made this book less like a novel and more like a work of art. It was beautiful. It was also the fastest book I have read all year and likely the very

Loved this fascinating story told in verse/texts/emails about a girl who gets surprising results from a DNA test. It almost gave me Where’d You Go Bernadette vibes, which is one of my favorite books. The voices are so distinctive and crisp and it makes me want to read more in this format!

5/5, will cry reading this again!

Dante Medema's debut novel is so lyrical and emotionally charged, I carried Cordelia's story with me every time I set the book down. A fresh take on the finding yourself archetype, spinning prose as precisely as a double helix, Medema used exactly the right amount of words to fill my heart with despair and love.
Books like these remind me of the love of reading, the love of poetry, the love of creating powerful narratives. Books like these are why I want to write. This is it.

Short read with a lot of verse. Since I have a friend who discovered her father was not her biological father through a DNA search I could recognize some of the emotional strain that can put on a family.

It’s a hella cool trick to tell an entire novel’s worth of twisty-turney story via poetry, and I’m always in awe of anyone who can pull it off. This one is no exception. Relationships bloom and die and bloom again; the complexities of family relationships are depicted with grace and grit. The main character travels an arc that forces her to question her loyalties—never easy for anyone, but particularly difficult for a teen. I loved the story’s tone of melancholy hope, and I look forward to readi

MY HEART!
(but also my lungs, cause this book is so beautiful I had trouble breathing while reading)

Stunning, gripping - discovering you're so much different, and yet also the same. Through the relationships with our families, friends, and the world, we come to understand ourselves. But anyone who has ever felt "outside" of their family, or wondered how they truly became who they are, will be moved to tears of sorrow and then absolute joy by Cordelia's journey! I'm not even a big crier and this story had me weeping - the ending brings it all to spectacular conclusion. The question of how we de

This book was SO GOOD. As an adopted kid who found her biological dad online, this book hit close to home, and the emotional journey felt so relatable and definitely had me sobbing a few times.

I was lucky enough to get to beta read The Truth Project. I was blown away by how heartfelt, honest, and beautiful the book is, and how well Dante navigated her story through verse.
Side note: I'm Kodiak's #1 fan. I LOVE him.

A beautiful novel in verse about a teen who discovers, through her senior genealogy project, that her father isn’t her biological father.

The emotional journey of self discovery that follows is raw and tangible. A lovely, lyrical book about the complications of family and identity.
I can't wait for the release. The little preview of the book sounds great. I know it will be one I can't put down.
A stunning debut in verse full of honesty and heart. And that cover!!!! Swoon

Thanks to the publisher and NetGalley for the early copy (even tho I read the hardcover from the library by the time I got around to it, oops)

Thank you to Unplugged Book and Edelweiss for this ARC. In exchange, here is my honest review.

As a poet, I adore the poetry style of writing. Moreover, the author also incorporated email and texting formats. The characters are all quite to-the-extreme, but relatable (depending on the reader, because each character is very different). Actually, reading about these characters made me reflect on myself and my actions.

The protagonist went through a tough time and made some “bad choices” –– she

The Truth Project takes readers on a journey that's just as much about Cordelia's outer world as it is her inner world. Cordelia's outer world is full of of what we'd expect for a high school senior: the navigation of friendships and relationships, learning how relationships to parents change as we grow up, and meeting the deadlines and expectations associated with a senior year project.

Cordelia's outer world gives readers plenty to think about and follow along with, but her inner world is where

Longer Review To Come Shortly: The Truth Project is a well-written, aptly pace exploration into what actually constitutes an identity.
Is it the truth you've always known? The secrets locked away in your DNA? Or is it neither of those things and only the facets you forge for yourself?
Combining fiction with a popular (and sometimes life-changing) fad of DNA/Ancestry tracing, Medema crafts a delicate coming of age tale for a new generation of readers.

Cordelia Koenig is wrapping up her senior year. She's already accepted an early decision invite to attend her first choice college, and she only has one last high school responsibility - completing her senior project. Cordelia has known she would use poetry as the method of delivery, but only recently has she decided to use the results of her ancestry DNA test as the topic for her work.

Always feeling like the odd one out in her family of mother, father, and two sisters, Cordelia is eager to see

Told through a series of emails, texts, and free verse poetry, The Truth Project tells a story of finding oneself and discovering that the family you choose is more important than the family DNA gives you.

A senior in high school, Cordelia was on the right track. She had early acceptance to college, loving parents - a typical model daughter. But when she consulted an ancestry site for her senior project and found unexpected results, Cordelia's whole world went into a tailspin. Caught between kno

What should have been a simple genealogy project becomes a life-changing discovery for Cordelia Koenig. The DNA results that reveal that her father is not who she thought he was confirm her worst fear: that the sneaking suspicion she does not quite fit in with her perfect family is not unfounded. So begins journey of self-discovery and identity that asks us what it means to truly belong somewhere.

The Truth Project is a quick read with a unique format. The multimedia storytelling – a mix of mediu

I'm always excited to read Alaskan authors, and it's an extra treat when the book is fantastic! This novel in verse, follows Cordelia Koenig as she embarks on a senior project that involves poetry and genealogy. When she sends in her DNA to GeneQuest as part of the project, her results are unexpected, sending her and her family into uncharted waters as she struggles to come to terms with what she knows. To complicate matters more, her partner in the senior project is longtime family friend, Kodi

Written in texts, e-mails and verse, the author manages to put a lot of emotion into every page.

I didn't know what to expect going into this book but I was pleasantly surprised by how easy it was to read and how emotional it was. I've never really read that much poetry so I was a little worried that I would find this story hard to follow as there are a lot of poems included as well as emails and text messages. However, I actually found this to be so unique and it kept my attention the whole way through and I enjoyed this particular type of storytelling.

I loved this book. It was a lovely and breathtaking look at what it means to search for yourself and your identity. All of us go through a sense of "self-discovery", especially as teenagers, and for Cordelia, this process takes on a much larger importance when she discovers that she isn't really who she always thought she was.

It's senior year, and Cordelia has already been accepted early decision into her top choice school. For her senior project, hoping to get a sense of who she is and continue

This book is stunningly beautiful. I read it in a sitting and the ending got me teary-eyed. I'm pretty new to novels-in-verse. I never gravitated toward them as a kid, or even as an adult, possibly because I'm autistic and find a lot of the metaphorical language that seems to come standard in poetry difficult to parse.

This book was riveting. Once I started, I couldn’t put it down. I’m always game for books with flawed characters, and Cordelia, although very likeable, makes a few big mistakes that make the story much more interesting. The cast of characters is small and focused, and they come together to tell an intricate, compelling story. The format was mixed media – verse, text, email. My favorite character was the best friend. She had a complex role in Cordelia’s arc that the author managed to tell exclusi

I read this book in one sitting. I loved the unconventional structure - the novel alternates between texts, emails and verse - which makes for a reading experience that's immediate, hard-to-put-down, and incredibly beautiful and lyrical. As Cordelia grapples with the unexpected results of a genetic test she takes for a school ancestry project, my heart ached for her. She's confused by what she's uncovered, and the foundations that she thought were firm beneath her have turned out to be not as so

I love that this is a story told in verse, text, and email. I think this will really be something students will latch on to and enjoy. It was a great way to read a story and possibly might be really accessible to reluctant readers. It is a coming of age story of a young girl who is looking to someday leave her small Alaskan town, and the discovery of who she is which I think will also really resonate with teens.

The Truth Project is an interesting read! Feeling a sense of not really belonging leads to a DNA search as part f a school project. Lots of life lessons in this book! Things are not always what they seem to be and sometimes the grass does look greener on the other side. Teens will like this story as it connects to friendships, family issues, finding a sense of belonging, and exploring who we are - or who we think we are. This book is well written and holds the reader's attention. This will be on

Thank you Netgalley for this ARC of The Truth Project by Dante Medema.

This is a story told in verse form, or through dialogues via email/text. It was a different and interesting way to read a story. Ultimately it's about a young girl who is looking to someday leave her small Alaskan town, and perhaps more about who she is.

I felt like this was an honest and heartbreaking story, and it shines a light on how mistakes of our past can effect us for years. I did find myself frustrated with pretty muc

I really liked the premise of Medema's novel-in-verse: that the protagonist, Cordelia, is thrown into an identity crisis by the results of a DNA test that suggests she isn't who she thought she was. The novel deals well with the icky toxicity of family secrets, and the ways in which ignorance can be both blissful and poisonous.

Given the complexity of what Cordelia discovers, though, I felt the conclusion was a little too tidy--all the conflict gets resolved in one evening at a poetry competitio

Absolutely loved this YA debut set in Alaska. The free verse, texts, & emails are woven so firmly into the meta plot that it felt perfect and right. Delia's poetry felt like the same angst I, and I'm sure multitudes of poetry-scribbling girls, went through in high school. Kodiak Jones is just dreamy and I loved that Delia could see right to the heart of him when she describes him as bursting forth like an eagle when he sang his poetry. Each one of Medema's characters stood out, from the Shakespe

What an excellent verse novel! In this book, Cordelia thinks she knows who she is and is ready to prove it with her senior project by researching get accessory through a DNA genetic test. However, when she gets her results, she finds that not everything is as it seems. The rest of the novel explores her spiraling thoughts and emotions as she freaks with the truth she wasn't expecting. Get reactions are so authentic, and I love her dynamic with her friend and Kodiak, her love interest and senior

I found that this book spoke to me, as a child of a non-conventional family. The anger that Cordelia feels toward her mom is tangible and something I felt with my whole body thanks to Dante’s descriptive writing.
It makes you think about the people in your life that help form who you are and which people are truly important to you when it feels that everything is on the line.
I read this book in two sittings and at times had to stop to sit with specific words and phrases. It pushed me to reach ou

How am I possibly supposed to use words to describe a book that already uses all the words so perfectly? Seriously.

This isn't my first book in verse, but I don't gravitate towards them often. But after this, I am absolutely changing that. I read this book in one sitting and it was so moving and heartfelt and sad, but also hopeful.

The characters were flawed, but there was such a depth to them, even with so few words, and I completely lost myself in Cordelia's story. I swooned with her, I cried w

Overall, a good read. My main issue lies within the writing. Free verse can be wonderful for showing emotion through formatting and white space. It becomes a problem, however, when a writer relies heavily on only the formatting to produce emotion rather than the formatting and the writing. The writing, overall, could have been stronger. In some spots, we're outright told the emotion ("anger"), which is made to look clipped/angry via line breaks, when we should have been shown that emotion vi

The Truth Project is about Cordelia, a teenage girl who lives in Kenai, Alaska with her family. For her senior project, she takes a DNA test with the idea to write poems about who she discovers she is as she delves into her ancestry. When her results reveal that the man who raised her is not her biological father, it rocks her whole world and sense of self.

Written all in the form of texts and poems, this book is an emotional page turner. I could feel not only the anguish of Cordelia, but also th

As a children's bookseller, I usually don't read YA. But I was so lucky to have gotten the advance reader's edition of this book. I read it in one sitting. A captivating story written in an uncommon form, the languages are simple but imagery and beautiful. I read some of the sentences repeatedly.

A seemingly scandalous discovery lead the main character Cordelia to discover the true characters of her family members. A seemingly lonely journey ended with the realization of how loved and supported

Cordelia is a senior working on her school project. She decides to do the same one her sister did years before: trace-your-roots genealogy. The only problem is the results reveal that her biological dad is not who she was raised by and this new knowledge rocks her world. Now she questions everything about herself and feels that her life has been a lie. She reconnects with a boy she grew up with and is able to confide in him as well as her best friend as she tries to make sense of this new inform

Wow, I flew through this in one evening! Cordelia’s search for her identity and struggle to determine where she fits in her family, in her friendships, and in her poetry was painful and beautiful to experience. I especially appreciated the glimpses into the stories of those around her because, after all, we don’t exist in a vacuum and everyone has gone through something, too. I loved the culmination and resolution of the book. I bawled. 💜

I had the opportunity to read an arc of this wonderful boo

"I received a complimentary copy of this book through NetGalley. Opinions expressed in this review are completely my own."
I loved this book. I started it last night and ended up staying up until I finished it. I really enjoyed the style of writing; the combination of email, text, and poetry. It was unique and engaging, but done so artfully that it just felt natural. The main character, Cordelia, had a beautiful story arc and her character seemed well developed. I highly recommend this book.

A beautiful and luminous story of searching, belonging, pain, and ultimately, where we find love. I read this in 1 day and I can't wait to see what Dante Medema has for us next!

Representation: Half-Tlingit love interest, lesbian Japanese best friend, Indian teacher

CW: Alcohol use, abortion mention (off the page, prior to the start of the book, experienced by a side character)

My first ever actual review....but this one is worth it. So beautifully written. I started the book, and couldn’t stop until it was over. I think I’ll still be emotionally invested in these characters for a whole bit.

Again, beautifully written. I felt so connected to the characters. The writing style was so different, I was actually worried I might have a hard time getting into it. I was obviously wrong. What a beautiful story.

This brilliant debut by Dante Medema is about Cordelia, an Alaskan teen poet whose senior genealogy project leads to a discovery that rocks her world. Her poems and texts form the majority of the book, and the creative way of portraying the story is natural and clever at the same time. I loved the main character and her family and friends, including some welcome diversity in the cast. Plus, all the feels you'd expect from a great young adult novel!

How can you complete a genealogy project, when you are not sure your parents are being truthful about your roots? Cordelia may find answers, but do those answers really help or has her life just been totally turned upside down?

Excellent read about family and what makes you family.
Creative book written in verse, emails, texts. Love the complexity of emotions throughout! Young adult novel

Cordelia Koenig is a seventeen-year-old senior in Alaska. All of her life she has left like she didn't quite belong. A senior project has Cordelia learning things about her life that has her world spiraling out of control. Written in the form of poems, text messages, and emails, this story is a quick read, and one that I couldn't stop.

I just finished this book and it was so lovely. It's a really fast read with super accessible prose for any level of YA reader, but the poetry and imagery give it a literary feel. My only regret is the story had to come to an end! I loved the novel-in-verse format and can't wait to see more from this author.

Favorite book this year. Grips your heart and doesn't let go. As someone who grew up in Alaska it resonates so strongly. It's so beautifully written, a poetic epistolary of a senior in high school struggling to know who she is while what she has known falls apart. I started it last night and finished in the morning as I could not put it down.

Wow! Amazing! I started this last night and finished today! New record for me! I absolutely loved how short the chapters were! 5 star read for me, writing was brilliant kept me intrigued and wanting to know more. Even made me cry! Loved it! Highly recommend this novel and I am curious to read more from Dante Modena!

Original, lyrical and gripping, I cared so much about all the characters and loved this self-discovery, coming of age story of Delia. And dang it, the author left me teary-eyed with those Dad scenes. Five stars all the way.

This book is a beautiful blend of verse and epistolary, with a memorable main character and really terrific supporting cast. It deals with heavy family issues with a deft hand. It's deeply felt and really memorable.

Where (and who) we come from is a fascinating subject, and Dante Medema’s THE TRUTH PROJECT explores the concept beautifully and earnestly. Written in poems, emails, and texts, this book has all the feels, from heartache to friendship, love, lies, mistakes, and healing. Highly recommend.

This. Book. Was. AMAZING! I finished it in a few hours and couldn’t put it down. The writing style was incredible and the characters made me feel so many emotions. I definitely recommend this book to everyone!

This was an emotional story that I loved!! The characters and story were beautifully done and I could not put this one down. The family themes in this story will make you cry and laugh and just feel so much for the MC.

an emotional, heartfelt, raw identity crisis told in verse. i floored through it in a day. the free verse gave deep insight into Cordelia and the turmoil of emotions she’s thrown into. i felt this book like she felt it.

This was my first novel in verse (there's also mixed media interspersed) and I really enjoyed it! It's such a heartbreaking topic and it's handled beautifully through the poetry and I ended up in tears a couple times. Definitely recommend!

Raw and so insightful!

Wow, this had me straight from the gates! It was so relatable you found parts of yourself in each character! I would recommend this to everyone! Gripping and honest!

As someone with a complicated relationship with my dad, this book hits hard. I love that the stakes aren't life and death, but Cordelia's ability to tell others what she's going through. I genuinely recommend this to anyone looking for a cathartic read with an HEA.

In the vain of many YA novels written in verse, this one is a standout! Following Cordelia’s path to her “true” identity and the truths she unfolds along the way was engrossing. I’m always amazed when an author can create a novel in verse that absolutely swallows the reader whole. Medema does that.
This sounds so good, I'm looking forward to reading.

Book 5/7 for the Reading Rush

RTC!

I am normally an iffy consumer of verse, but I really loved this one.

Things I liked: the characters were so relatable, the format felt very authentic, and the poems were lovely.
Such a beautiful and emotional book. I love this novel with all of my heart <3
I love poetry so I thought this book was cool as it expressed all her thoughts and emotions throught that mode. But overall I wasn't overally into it. It was a cool concept though!
What a beautifully written story about finding what makes you, you!
I enjoyed this book so much, I could not put it down. A beautifully woven story of a girl’s search for self and what part nature vs nurture play. Highly recommend!
Carefully and wonderfully written. My only wish was for a little more closure with her mother.
I read this in an hour and a half and it made me cry. I'm fragile.
Solid and lyrical read for YA.

Junk Boy by Tony Abbott is a surprisingly moving novel written in verse. The story follows Bobby who is nicknamed "junk" by his bullying classmates. Bobby lives in a run down house on the outskirts of town with his neglectful father and a yard littered with junk. He is sad, alone, bullied and hungry. First of all, I (at 52) have watched Gabbie on YouTube with my son, since she started 6 years ago. She has definitely grown both as a person and an entertainer. During the years of watching her videos and find Gabbie to be very down to earth person; honest and caring. Love her music, too! Now, about her books...Enjoyed “Adultolescence” a lot and “Dandelion” is another winner! Bravo Gabbie! Love your words, thoughts and drawings! Keep up the great work.

Her greatest work! Adultolescence will always hold a dear place in my heart but in Dandelion, Gabbie Hanna confesses much deeper and more heartbreaking truths. The confessionary tales of Dandelion paint out the purest forms of struggle, pain, and melancholy. It’s a must in the small portion of great poetry books!

This book was BEAUTIFUL. The part that sold it for me was the letters to strangers in the back (Barnes and Nobles edition). It showed how important the smallest of moments can be to the people we don't even acknowledge in our narratives. They gave a whole new meaning to the ideology of being the ” main character”, Stunning.
I absolutely loved it! I’m a huge fan of her writing and music!
Didn't enjoy as much as their first, but still raw and deep look into one person's journey. The illustrations are stories of their. Classic and modern formats used.
The best way to enjoy is to not have expectations. It is not a grand display of deep poetry, it is a collection of art pieces with individual humor and hurt and experiences that can be shared.

To be completely honest, I loved reading this book. I I I could tell that Gabbie poured her heart into the illustrations, the poems, and especially the memoir at the end. While yes, some poems are just thoughts, they are thoughts that I have also had but never knew how to write or share, and Gabbie does. And she does it beautifully, artistically, which is part of who she is. An artist, a creator. She wears her heart on her sleeve each time she puts out a new work, and Dandelion is her heart, her

I was worried that this book would be disappointing since I've developed a more critical eye since I read Adultolescence 6 times in 8th grade. Fortunately, I still loved it! Lots of metaphors really made me stop and think, and I believe that this may be better than her first book. 3 years was definitely worth the wait! Also, my Target edition extras were amazing too!

PS. It technically took me one day to read this book seeing as I restarted it after finishing and read up to the part I stopped at.
love it

Even better than Adultolescence, I enjoyed Dandelion immensely. Gabbie has grown both as a poet and a person and Dandelion's poems are less superficial and far deeper than I expected after having read her first collection.

I bought the book and I was way more impressed with her first one. Dandelion reads like a bunch of tweets with a poetic tilt but no actual development. Some of the poems were okay at best. She's a better storyteller than a poet.

Also she's begging her Patreon subscribers to leave five star reviews and amp up the book's rating which REALLY rubs me the wrong way

I know Gabbie is a “problematic” YouTuber but I’ve always liked her! I love her comedy, her music and now her books! I understand her pain so I really understand a good amount of her poetry! The only reason I couldn’t give it 5 stars is the nude pictures and the diversity of poems. I can tell how much work she put into it though! And definitely better than her first book!!
Actually really loved this 😌 I was a little nervous after these last few years, but her music and writing is so amazing and you can't argue that to me.

this book takes surface level to a whole new level !! this collection of poems was so unreadably terrible , i laughed so much. it was the novelisation of the “i’m 14 and this is deep” meme, the “s(he ) be(lie)ve(d)” in poetic constructs. i would put it nicer , but it was a waste of paper.
This was ✨ horrible ✨

Better than her freshman book as it seems like there are less plagiarized tweets to fill space and she actually credits her sisters for contributing this time, but still a vanity puff piece. I managed to finish the book in a day, which is not a testimony to how good the book is. The majority of the poems were so vapid and shallow, there was no need to reread to digest their full meaning like a good poem will make you do. The themes seem to be more mature than Adultolescence, but also shallow at

i rlly liked this. i’m not a huge poetry person but i really loved a lot of these poems. i have always like gabbie even through the scandals so yeah i just rlly enjoyed these. the drawings are all rlly cute. also i love the little i think they’re mice or rats on some of the pages. i just rlly enjoyed it and the stories at the back were really nice to read. this was super cute and deep and the drawings were great and i just enjoyed this a lot.
I loved every bit of this

i read one page.

that was more than enough.
Such cute illustrations and very fun to read. Very relatable

This book is absolutely amazing, like yesssss Goodbye is by far my favourite even I it isn’t a poem (I haven’t gotten the B&N edition so another favourite might be in that one) because it hits so close to home, most of my internet friends have been made because of you so thank you for that💛
the art is amazing and the poems are brilliant and the vocabulary makes me who likes big words exited to learn the new ones just thanks for being alive you’ve helped so many with your art and I cannot thank y

This book is truly amazing. Though it isn't "traditional" poetry, I really do truly feel that this is a good book. Gabbie explores topics often untouched and seen as taboo. If nothing else, it's something you can read when you want to feel a little less alone in your dark, confusing, scary, conflicting thoughts.

I love how you can definitely see Gabbies love for Bo burnham and Shel Silverstein in this book. Not only is it a look into Gabbies own mental health and personal struggles but the version that I have has “the stories I have to be drunk to tell” personal essays and they hit so close to home for me. Thank you so much Gabbie for writing this.

Wow, what a disappointment. I truly wished she would have listened to critiques, spent a couple years in writing workshops, and strengthened her writing ability. The poems seem like unfinished first drafts of ideas for poems, yet she is charging people money for them. Gabbie, please take poetry classes. Do the work. Earn the respect of poetry lovers beyond your immediate fan base.

So, I did not like Gabbie’s first book, for my own personal reasons. And with Dandelion being published, I have quite low expectations and I’m not really anticipating much. But, I’ll give Gabbie another chance. Review coming soon.

Curiosity lead me to reading this book. I’ve watched Gabbie Hanna’s videos on YouTube before, and I saw the high ratings for this (on Amazon, that is.) Reading this between other books because I figured it would be a simple read, I was able to finish it in an hour or so. It’s very simple and accessible. I suspect the targeted demographic was preteens, which is why I personally rate the poems 2-2.5 stars.

Gabbie’s approach was to write about how much she loved a guy, and then the next poem would

Good book however, I pre-ordered and didn't get my coloring book or snack book. I emailed 5 times and heard nothing. Heard nothing in my promotions, nothing in spam. NOTHING! If Gabbie you are seeing this, when will I be hearing from atriapreorder@simonandschuster.com?

I got this book for my birthday and absolutely loved it!! I’m not usually an avid poetry reader however I find myself rereading some of these ones. It is deep, raw, and yet has humor sprinkled in too! In my personal opinion even better than her first book! I would definitely recommend.

Gabbie has a unique style that I appreciate so much. She’s not afraid to stand out and be her own and this poetry book certainly shows that. So happy I pre-ordered it, it was worth the read. I recommend it to anyone who likes stuff that is out of the ordinary, unique and honest.

This book is amazing from the gut wrenching story’s to the heart felt poems, loves it very much, I got the Barnes and nobles edition wich I really recommend because the letters to strangers part had me in tears. Very highly recommended, very good book!.

I was really disappointed, this is essentially just a book of tweets. In fact, one of the ‘poems’ is literally a tweet from July last year, and while that’s the only one I’ve physically seen I have no doubt there’s more. I had higher hopes for this but honestly don’t waste your money. She’s also requested on her Patreon for people to flood the reviews with five star reviews because there are ‘too many one stars’.
Loved it!!
I love Gabs and her books are amazing, clever, and in depth

I'm gonna have to disagree with a lot of people here. First, this isn't really a poetry book, and I don't think it was supposed to be. Some entries are poems, some are just random thoughts, there are illustrations galore, and I think it's meant to be taken as a whole, not in parts. That's not to say it's *good* but I don't think it's bad either. For what it is, I honestly enjoy it. It feels like a peek into Gabbie's mind rather than serious prose, and that's just the sort of thing I eat up.
Why do people keep calling this "poetry"? This is not poetry, it's tumblr content.

I know a lot of people really aren’t a fan of hers, and I think all the reasons are very valid.

I really enjoyed her first poetry collection, and I know a of people didn’t. I was eager to pick up this one. I will say, I think I liked her first collection a little bit better, but I might have to go back for a reread.

I did listen to this on audio because I think there’s a real value in hearing someone read their own work, especially something so autobiographical.

Actual rating: 3.5/5 stars.

This was fun to read! Much like Gabbie's first book, there were some poems I liked and some I didn't. The art, though, was gorgeous and a joy to see sprinkled throughout the book. I bought the Barnes and Noble edition and really enjoyed the Letters to Strangers segment at the end.

4 stars. I liked it more than her first book. I do think it was better. You can see that she's grown as a writer. I listened to this so I don't get to comment on her art but I bet it was pretty and funny. I'd like to read it later on and annotate which were my favorites.
Absolutely loved it! I didn’t connect to all the poems, hence the 4 star rating. However, I still adored many and loved all the illustrations. My favorite poem was “Two.”

This book was a very refreshing and fun experience, with some dark topics that were made more bearable to analyze because of the careful wording and involved illustrations. I placed a small heart sticker in the top corner of each of the pages that contained poems that either especially spoke to me or made me laugh. This is my absolute favorite book. I have been watching/listening to Gabbie Hanna since Vine (RIP). Although she is my favorite artist, I always listen to her music and read her books with an open mind and I try to be as impartial as I can, and every time she never fails to amaze. I strongly, truly feel that when she was doing vine and back when she was TheGabbieShow, she was more loud and dramatic (like a normal young adult); but when that was who she was, that is also who I was. As she grew up

There’s relatability in this and the poems have improved slightly, in my opinion, since the last one: “Adultolescence”. However, I still don’t find these types of “poems” to even be poetry, and Gabbie Hanna certainly doesn’t manage to convince me that they are. That being said, the “poems” that were longer than 1-5 lines were much better than the shorter ones.
Most of these “poems” just fall victim to the same old thing that happens every time I read these sorts of books: they come off like twee

Rather than stay safe with just simple, short, fun poems, Gabbie reveals her darkest vices through such intricate and harrowing forms of symbolism weaved into stories of trauma, fear, and despair. Yet, Gabbie utilizes her creativity to transform these into much more than just “stories”. Her artwork is just as wondrous, creating

I believe if you liked her other book you will enjoy this one, I, however, do not share the sentiment. I wanted to see growth from her writing however it remained pretty much the same (very 2013 tumblr post-esc), with few minor exceptions (being a slight effort in the form). The rhythm is off, it's wrong and boring and that makes the poems hard to read. Sometimes you think she is going to give a poem a steady beat but suddenly it falls flat (not only in the rhythm but also in creativity). The la

I’ve been so excited for this book since early this year when she announced she was working on it. I knew I’d enjoy it but it came to me in an important time of my life. I related to so many of the poems and experiences. There were a few poems that seem to eloquently word some of my emotions, thoughts, and experiences. This book is a pertinent part of my healing process in a way I didn’t expect :) I’m definitely going to read it again and start writing my own poetry.

Gabbie’s poetry is a bit difficult for me. It’s always a good, easy read, but it rarely makes me feel anything on any sort of a deep level. I feel that Gabbie is much better at expressing things through music, or through simply talking out loud. The poetry never speaks to me the way her music does, but maybe that’s because when I’m reading it, it’s my own voice inside my own head so it doesn’t give the same impact.

However, I bought this particular edition of the book for the memoirs, and those

This sophomore collection of illustrated poems was very cute. I never read Gabbie Hanna’s first poetry collection, but after finishing this one, I wanted to buy it. It was a breezy read with short poems and illustrations on each page. Because of how easy the poems were to read and how curious I was to see what the next one would have in store, I ended up finishing this collection in one sitting.

I’ve never been a huge fan of poetry, but this is a book I can get behind. Some poems have multiple meanings, some really hit you in the feels and others are silly to balance out the reality of the tragedy that brought all these words out. Dandelion had me glued to its pages, only pausing to admire the drawings scattered throughout. The memoirs at the end also give a glimpse at the tragedies that were made into a work of art. If you consider yourself a poetry connoisseur, Dandelion will change y

While I enjoyed 'Adultolescence', her first collection of poetry, 'Dandelion' portrays much more deeper stories and thoughts. It's nice that they bounce back and forth between long, short, funny, insightful, angry, and emotional. Like much poetry, while they don't always resonate with me personally, there are a few that really put into words emotions and thoughts that I haven't quite been able to identify before. A lot of her "poems" kind of feel just like tweets. Though I enjoyed reading this and don't regret taking the time to do so, I would rather have not paid full price for it. Gabbie is controversial for several reasons, I have had a complicated relationship with her as an on again off again fan for the past 4 years. I can tell that this book was well thought out and reads like the great Shel Silverstein. It's a perfect book to put on the coffee table to have people peruse when they are awkwardly sitting on your couch or a book to put on your night stand and treat yourself to on poem a night to. Gabbie puts out a real showstopper with this book. There are poems that can relate to almost all people; the silly, happy, sad, depressed, moody, excited, etc. Depending on the book version you got, there are tons of extras that add into the life of Gabbie Hanna! You can see the effort and hard work that she and her team put i to this, and I feel that poetry should become a norm in everyone’s lives, starting with Dandelion.

I absolutely adore this book. I also read her previous book, Adultolecense, which I also enjoyed. Dandelion goes deeper. Are there short, cutesy poems? Yes. There are also long, more thought provoking poems as well. It’s a mixture. It’s a very whimsical book that take you on a rollercoaster of emotions. From happy and whimsy to heart wrenching. Gabbie really shows a deeper look inside her mind and it is absolutely wonderful!

Gabbie can really set a scene, damn. I have only read the letters to strangers so far and her writing really reels you in and keeps you hooked. She has such an elegant and fluid style, her poetry is incredibly moving and poignant. I felt so much from her poetry, I could feel her pain and certain poems really touched me and hit me with a flood of emotions, especially Feel and Sever. Thank you Gabbie for your words.

I’ve never really been into poetry books but when Gabbie Hanna came out with her first book adultolescence I fell in love with poetry. When she said that she was coming out with this book dandelion I was excited so I bought 5copies of the book because I love and support her. this book hits different emotions some are happy, sad and I love how each and every poem just flows so smoothly in the book. It’s a book that I highly recommend.

I love poetry books because you can most of the time find meaning that relates to your life. I have both of Gabbie’s books and love them both. They speak to me in a way that makes me feel like I’m not alone. That I’m not the only one who is gone through some shit. Her writing, her songs, and what she speaks about on YouTube speak out to so many of us. Keep writing, keep singing, and keep doing what your doing Gabbie.

I absolutely love this book. There are so many pages that explain my exact situation and it hits home. Gabbie has been through so much and this book captures maybe 50% of it, which is amazing. She’s so artistic in every way and I love that she’s able to express her feelings and her experiences through her art. Gabs, thank you for this masterpiece. Your artwork, strength, and perseverance inspires me to be a better person every day. Love you long time 💕

A lot of people have a hate-on for this book, but for me it was just genuinely a fun read. It is filled with simple, fun poems, illustrations, limericks and stories that give you a look into the way the author has experienced life and the world, many of which are relatable, make you laugh, or just make you feel some type of way. I love the mix of silly and sad, of thoughtful narratives and throwaway 2-line poems that make you snort and lighten the mood.

most of the reviews on this clearly haven’t read the book. is this the best poetry out there? absolutely not. is it trash and doesn’t deserve to be read? also absolutely not. the poems are good for what they are, they’re not professional, they’re made from passion. i read the Barnes and Noble exclusive, and the Letters To Strangers section was easily my favorite part. people hate this book because it’s Gabbie Hanna and it’s easy to hate her work.

Gabbie Hanna does it again! Some poems are short and comedic while others are long and thoughtful. No matter what, they make you think. Her playfulness with the illustrations and titles also help to form the reader's thoughts and opinions. We also see her open up a bit in the original print with her memoirs like we've never seen before. I'm looking forward to reading her Letters to Stangers in the Barnes & Noble edition soon!

This book is beyond incredible. I have loved Gabbie’s poetry for years. Who knew I could love it even more? Well this book made love it more. The poems are so real and relatable. It spoke to me so much. The poems are so raw and really show the battle with mental health. I recommend this book to any poetry fan!

I read her last book and have always loved her poetry but dandelion to me had more deeper poetry. I love the deep hidden messages and themes she has in Dandelion. I got them primary edition so I only had the short stories at the end which shown a depth perspective on some of the abuse she shared from her life. She did a really great job!!

This book is absolutely beautiful. Gabbies went and made a beautiful piece of art again. I love how at face value her poems will seem like one thing, then when you take the title, poem before or after, or the illustration paired with it into account it has a whole other meaning to it. I can relate to so many of the poems in this book and I’m so happy Gabbie wrote this.

It’s a great balance of lighthearted levity and genuine rawness. I finished it in less than 24 hours and I couldn’t keep it down. It’s engrossing and it’s nothing but honest in the best way. The only problem with it is that there wasn’t enough, her inspiration is very apparent in the pages and her hard work shows in the quality.

Honestly amazing!
This books is even better than adultolescence
(That’s a great book too) It’s so creative and clever. I love how gabbie writes in a way that what is said can be taken in so many different ways. This also makes it a good book to lend to others to see what there thoughts of different poems are and mean to them.
Love this book so much!

This is the most beautiful book I have ever read. The poems in this book are ridiculously creative, deep and emotional. It’s full of humour and relatable situations but also some break taking upsetting moments that’ll make you cry. Whether you like the author or not this is a book you will 100% enjoy.

Shout out to all the people who bought her book just to hate on the low-key poems. I read her poems, the serious and silly ones, and loved all of them. Gabbie Hanna is very much a poet even if some of the poems are two lines, y'all are just salty that she's popular and you aren't. Love all of her work definitely give her book a read if you're looking for some good poetry.

I Bought Adultolescence when Gabbie announced she was releasing a new book- Dandelion- and it quickly became one of my favorite books! Naturally i immediately pre-ordered Dandelion. I am about half way through the book now and i could not have prepared myself for how incredible the writing and illustrations are!!! cant recommend this book enough!!

I think I would have really been into this when I was in my early twenties. This collection (I cant call them poems) was very angsty and depressing. Most of the book were short observations with a few poems sprinkled throughout. The last section was a collection of letters. It was there that the writing felt more purposeful for me.

I enjoyed this book a lot. Was the poetry a masterpiece? No. But I also didn’t expect it to be. I could tell it was real. It had a lot of heart behind it, and I related to most of it. I think it was a 4 star read before the last 20 or so pages. I absolutely loved the section of “Stories I Have to Get Drunk to Tell” essays. ❤️

Did not like the first book Gabbie came out with. This one is a masterpiece . I felt like she actually put a huge amount of effort and her best work yet. Loved the connection to this and it didn't feel force or like she needed to write poems just to write them. I also loved the last part of her childhood stories , crazy how traumatic some experiences are. Loved this book so much !!

Much like Adultolescence, I genuinely don't know if I like or dislike Dandelion. I do think the price is high and I have an Overdrive account so I checked out the audiobook for free. I had moments where I cringed, and yet I was enthralled with some of her stories (being a trauma survivor myself). 3 stars is the most neutral review I give.

I was hoping this would be better than her first book and I will say the more longform prose writing at the end of the book was more interesting to read about her life growing up and some assaults' she has lived through. The "poetry" however is the same - it reads like twitter drafts. Gabbie - write more about your experiences like at the end of this book and you could put out a decent book.

In the first page she talks about how her grandmother kept her first poem from 2004, okay she's basically gone downhill since then. I went into this not knowing anything about the writer. There was some so-so stuff, but overall it was not good. Plus she writes mostly short poems and then does 10 short stories??? It just doesn't mess well.

Great poetry book with a mix of really deep sad poems that are pretty spot on and a couple of jokes that make it a bit more light hearted I got the verisimilitude with the memoirs and honestly (no pun intended) it was really cool to learn a bit more about gabbie and how she became who she is

can y’all actually read the book before you give it a bad rating jfc. some of the poems are jokes but but most of them are very vulnerable and real. both books have helped me feel validated during really tough times ty gabbie for sharing a piece of yourself with us <3

Very good book! i totally recommend this book if you are one to have an open mind on things if you don’t like it you just don’t like her it’s really that simple poetry is very subjective and can be literally ~whatever~ you want it to be!

PHENOMENAL BOOK! my favourite poetry book hands down! Gabbie’s poems are so relatable! If you haven’t read it please do.. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND! Dandelion is one of those books you can’t put down until you’ve read the entire thing in one sitting!

Amazing book! The flow of the entire book and the way the pages interact with one another is incredible. I highly recommend actually reading this book and giving it a chance because it is honestly so beautiful, sometimes heartbreaking, but still beautiful <3

This book is beautiful I absolutely adored it! Letters to strangers was my favorite edition it made me cry so much it’s beautiful how Gabbie really sees people, even the ones she doesn’t personally know. I read my mom a few exerts and she cried as well. Well done Gabbie!

Gabbie is one of my favorite Youtubers so as soon as she wrote this book I knew I had to buy it and read it asap! Some people think that since she's a YouTuber that she can't write good books or sing good music. I love absolutely EVERYTHING she creates! And this book is AMAZING!!! 1,000,000 STARS!!

Gabbie Hanna’s writing and illustrating skills are both impeccable. Of course, she isn’t perfect and not everybody will agree but, you could say the same for any other writer. Personally, I think her poetry is interesting, innovative, and beautiful.

Silverstein Vibes FOR DAYSSSS. As someone who grew up reading poetry books, this book and others really hit home. Whether they’re short poems, or long ones, they’re today’s society written in poem form. Really great read.

This started out really good. The first few poems really were deep and I truly enjoyed them. Then it seemed to go down hill from there. I know nothing about the author and I did not read her first poetry book. This felt disjointed and some just seemed to be angry text messages.
2.5 stars. Right in the middle. I really respect Gabbie, and there was some really good stuff in here. But overall, there were a lot of filler poems and way-too-rhymey poems.
I love the Letters to Strangers at the end.
Her poems we super in the lines but other ones gave you deep thoughts . its covered I,sticky notes now from all the poems I loved
Reading it with my bf and we're both enjoying it alot :)
Gabbies Poetry was amazing in this book and her drawings never fail to amaze me. Just like adultolecense this is another win.

I had been wanting to read this book for so long, but was deterred by the price. But then, why worry about price when I have a darling who buys me such books? ‘The Boy, the Mole, the Fox and the Horse’ is everything that it is made out to be. It’s beautiful, kind, lovely, warm, and just what we need in these times.

Also, the kind words here are what we need to practice. Sometimes, I wonder why we read? Merely to prattle about it on our blogs or to really practice the lessons that books give us?

I make no apologies for having a wide sentimental streak through me, and this little gem is like Bactine for the soul (my grandma said it was the cure for everything that hurt). Whimsical drawings and an unexpected friendship among unlikely creatures bring us a sense of calm in the storm. There's nothing earth shattering in the wisdom offered, just sweet reminders to focus on that which heals and connects and supports. A great gift book for younger people.

An interesting, well-produced collection of poetry by Lana Del Rey, one of my favourite contemporary music artists. The collection starts off excellently with the first poem “LA Who Am I To Love you”, which tells of Del Rey yearning for LA after moving to San Francisco and feeling out of place there. The rest of the collection was a bit of a mixed bag for me.

Like her lyrics, many of these poems have an atmospheric, nostalgic feel to them. They read like diary entries, often chronicling a painful

Real poets don't have to try so hard to persuade their readers on every poem that they are real poets.

(Let's not forget she promised to sell the collection for no more than $1 "because my thoughts are priceless" (rolling my motherfucking eyes) and then she backed-out from the idea.)

I don't know how other people are not seeing the pretentiousness in this.

Update: Apparently the money was donated to the Navajo Water Project, which is great! I still believe the "book" is trash however.

In case there was any doubt, Lana is not a pop singer, she’s a poet who makes music. Perfect words put in the perfect order to create perfect feeling. I’ll revisit it again and again. Also, all profits go to reparations for Native American people, so why not get the audiobook and the hard copy?

i live for that first second in the morning

i hear the flower

Once, there were these poems,
Which my heart cannot fully bear.
Drivel — daft and dreary,
Perchance, all I can do is but stare.

Enjambments and aphorisms, likewise,
Have filled this book,
Hackneyed phrases — oh bloody hell,
Seems like gobbledygook!

Prithee, to thee, I say —
Analyse her poems first from within,
And compare its content
From Lord Byron's discipline:

"When we two parted
In silence and tears,
Half broken-hearted
To sever for years,
Pale grew thy cheek and cold,
Colder thy kiss;
Truly that hour

i hold
the pages
that give my heart
a place
to call home
while words of
simple elegance
and subtle purity
teach it
to grow
and inspire it
to love.

Punching the Air is a powerful collaborative novel in verse, drawing from Salaam's experience wrongly incarcerated as teen.
Amal means hope, but he isn't left with much of it when a choice to go along with friends ends in a fight that puts someone in a coma and Amal is charged for it. Even though he argues his innocence, advice to take a plea deal means he is facing a long time in prison. Yet with seemingly everything against him, he finally finds his hope in art and poetry while behind bars.

This is a powerful novel in verse that is a great choice for teens and adults interested in social justice. The imagery is so striking in this novel - near the beginning of the story the authors compare the handcuffs placed on Amal with the shackles of enslaved people and I can't get that image out of my head. If you're a fan of Walter Dean Myers or Jason Reynolds, this is the book for you.

A fast read, but one that leaves a mark.

Trethewey writes prose the way you’d expect a poet to write: musical, evocative, compelling. As with all good memoirs, it’s much more than the recounting of a life. In this case, it’s the record of the author’s own struggle to come to grips with a painful past.

On the other hand, it's more fun to read these verses and limericks with relief now that the Trump tenure is coming to an end. Actor and writer John Lithgow is in high command of words and uses them to delightful effects.

I don't know the terms for all the kinds of rhyming poetry, but these are verses written during the Senate impeachment trial and the early COVID lockdown. They are time capsules of the zillions of absurdities that have occurred within the past 11 months. Brilliant, Witty Poetry In These Despotic Times.

We have been fans of John Lithgow since Harry and the Henderson days. I surprised my husband with a *pray hands* THANK YOU B&N signed copy for our anniversary, and it made. His. Day. Seriously, he felt like he won the lottery. My daughter ended up reading through the book and loved it. Lithgow's entertaining and thoughtful prose lends a cautionary tale and a lyrical regaling of the horror story that has been the last four years of Trumpty Dumpty in

Multi-award winning Actor John Lithgow offers his brilliant interpretation of what we've experienced the last 4 nightmare years with the Trump Administration in Trumpty Dumpty Wanted a Crown: verses for a Despotic Age (pp. 104). His writing, his imagination and his illustrations are terrific. If you're a fan of Lithgow who's has had a remarkable acting career-I'll watch him anything-this book doesn't disappoint. Trumpty Dumpty is Shel Silversteinesque, but lacking the lyrical genius Silverstein brought to his work. The cartooning is nearly on par, and I don't disagree with the book's sentiments. The poems often seem forced, and usually are retelling of events. It lacks both punch and insightful wit. Rather than leaving me satisfied that a good joke has landed or a political point has been honed to sharp effect, I find myself feeling that perhaps returning to grading high school history papers might be a

Entertaining way to sear into your memory the fiasco named Trump

John Lithgow uses wit, intelligence and just plain common sense to pen a means for us to always remember the mendacity, hate, and greed of the Trump administration. As usual, his clever use of words creates an enjoyable read while conveying important truths.
Lithgow's ability to cut to the chase clarifies the last four years with intelligence and humor. Definitely a worthwhile read

Once again, John Lithgow has put the "Despotic Age" of Donald Trump into doggerel verse, with historical notes after each poem in case the reader has forgotten the events/people referred to. It's a fun read. Much more fun than living through the events. Also illustrated by Lithgow. A little pricey for such a slender volume ($23 for 104 pages, many of which are mostly his cartoons). But fun. I'd really like to do 3.5 stars.

I really enjoyed how his second book of Trumpty poems highlighted some of the heroes we've had these last four years. In his forward, he mention how so much changes in the time between writing and publishing book. It does boggle my mind how much has changed since June when he submitted the final draft to his publishers. It also boggles my mind to realize how many people have left 45's administration in just 4 years.

The novelty may have worn off a little with this sequel to Lithgow's previous (superior) DUMPTY, but it is still an immensely clever review of all things POTUS and his minions. You'll be surprised how many "characters" have come and gone through the White House and thankful the author has put it all in delirious context for you. Lithgow remains one of our finest American talents - is there anything the man can't do?

Love this!

This may be the best book of poetry I’ve ever read! Lithgow gets it right in every poem. Fun to read, and in many cases it brings back memories, since things have changed at such a rapid pace in the last four years, he reminds of the chaos we have lived through. I read this in one sitting of about an hour!

The multi-talented John Lithgow has done it again with a witty, comic, yet sadly true collection o poetry and limericks, each with a cogent explanation of the story behind each poem. The frosting on the cake are the illustrations, also penned by Lithgow, making this an apt read for this week in history.

This was my first Lithgow book so I was pretty impressed!...with the doodles, that is. The poems, however, got a bit boring. If the book was a bit shorter I would have been more content. That being said, I did also appreciate the brief explanation/reminder about each situation or political slimeball following each poem. That helped bring things together for me.

Excellent work, John Lithgo

This is savy, cute, cutting and dangerously true. Who knew you, John Lithgo, could do great line drawings and make sure that history is not rewritten. I am so much of a fan. Will give this book to many of my friends.

Absolutely fantastic entertainment!

For months now I have not been able to even watch the news as it concerns 45. This book is outrageously fun and tells the truth about his 'reign ' in the past year. If only it wasn't true!

John Lithgow hits the nail

There is something absurd afoot when the US people can seriously consider a President for a second turn who lies routinely and fires those who disagree. John Lithgow catches and condenses that to perfection.

"I'll settle for Trumpty, ex-president."

Best ending line ever and, talk about timing! As I devoutly hope, that last line will come to pass very very soon. I love John Lithgow's reading style, and that these rhymes were his very own is fantastic.

Author, satirist, and actor, John Lithgow uses humor and verse to remind us of the many scandals which have been buried by others in the relentless news cycle. It's terrifying to see them all load bare together as such and a reminder of the sheer absurdity of it all.

A reminder of crimes by an incompetent leader

We may never realize how lucky we are to have voted out such a despot but I hope we can take care to never repeat this dangerous experiment again.

Genious!

Absolutely genious! Looking forward to the next installment after the election. Its fun to revive this age old form of satire.

If ever there was a book to expose the failures and pointlessness of governments and local authorities, it was this one. This book made me fucking angry. The treatment of Sissay during his 17 years in care is an absolute fucking disgrace and everyone (save a couple of heroes he meets along the way) should be utterly ashamed of their involvement.

Sissay was left to swim against a tide of abuse, rejection and red tape, his only weapons his thirst for rebellion and obsession with Bob Marley.

The thru
Fantastic but heartbreaking read, devastating account of the treatment of children and systemic failures the care system in the UK.

"I am British. But I am also a first-generation Ethiopian. Ethiopia is not what we think of in this country. It is a profound place. I had to unlearn everything I had learnt about Africa and everything I had ever learnt about black people." 

My Name is Why is a scathing indictment of the British care system in the '80s. The same system that still fails many children to this very day. 

Lemn gives us a harrowing account of how his childhood was impacted by the multitude of failures and neglect by pe

“My mother is from the Amhara people of Ethiopia. It is a tradition of the Amhara to leave messages in the first name of the child. In Amharic the name Lemn means Why?”

The poet/playwright grew up thinking his name was Norman Greenwood. He was simply the oldest child of a white family near Wigan. Though they never formally adopted him, the Greenwoods were his long-term foster parents for 12 years. By adolescence he was perceived as being too difficult – for acts of rebellion normal for his age bu

Well I finished Lemn Sissay’s My Name Is Why today and immediately fell apart. I grieved this book. I grieved this childhood. A memoir about his theft in infancy from his Ethiopian mother’s care in a “home” for young mothers in rural England, through his failed white foster placement, and then through various boy’s “homes” until his own ingenuity springs him from the system, this is really a memoir about a beautiful boy who sows poetry from seeds of racism, and neglect, and abuse, and torture. T

Lemn tells an autobiography of his youth where he was placed into UK care soon after birth and fostered. The biography is supported with first hand reports that Lemn recovered from government files written at various times when he was a child.

He tells a sorrowful story of being let down by his foster family and the government agency. The beginning for me was fascinating, but as the book progressed, the reports took on more importance and it seemed like I was reading red tape rather than experie

I actually read My Name Is Why a few days back, but I really needed some time to fully digest my thoughts before typing up this review. This book will leave you angry, frustrated yet interested all at the same time. The shocking true events of Sissay himself being adopted and part of the social care system until adulthood and then learning the reality, the bigger picture that had been shielded from him all his life. Told in short chapters with images of social care reports included, it's a memoi
Lemn, I cheer your courage, your intelligence, your bravery, your voice.

Really recommend this book. Very powerful but not an easy read. Raises so many questions about identity, family dynamics, the times, unchallenged everyday racism, as well as humanity and the lack of humanity

A story that must be heard, no matter how painful. We seem to live in a society where blaming the unfortunate offers absolution for the conscience and justifies an underfunded, under-resourced care system that is far from ideal. Perhaps this book will change some minds.

How Lemn Sissay survived and turned out to be the man he is today is due only to the human spirit refusing to give in to the horrors heaped upon him as a youth.

This is yet another horrifying chronicle of those in charge of taking care of disadvantaged children failing in the most monstrous manner. And might I mention that this takes place in Great Britain the 1960’s, not the 1860’s.

In this case the original foster parents are the worst. How Christian people could treat a child in their care in

Unfortunately, this was quite a tedious read. I really did not like the way Sissay decided to format the book, with most of the narrative being told in social work/government entries, with little-to-no exposition made on Sissay's part; almost like inserting a quote in an essay and that being the sentence, with no analysis.

The story is tragic and should be told, I think I would have preferred the story to be completely narrative. I imagine I would have connected more and been able to visualise h

Devastating indictment of foster care, adoption, racism, and treatment centers especially for black children.

However, the construction of the book was terrible. Much of the book was photocopies of reports from his files (and then retyped). This stopped any narrative flow. I would have appreciated more story in his voice and files placed in footnotes or appendices or used more sparingly.
An incredibly moving memoir about the failure and systemic racism of the care system in Britain a few decades ago.

A fourteen-year old boy should never have to ask the questions Who is my mother? and Who are my family? These were not easy questions to formulate in the mind or the mouth because the question comes with others . . . What did I do to deserve this?


This memoir is poet Lemn Sissay's fact-finding mission into his own past. In 2015, after a 'thirty-year campaign' to be allowed to see his own records, Sissay finally discovers how and why he became a ward of the State and the official record of his

Lemn Sissay’s extraordinary and distressing story of his life in a foster home and then in local authority care is brought vividly alive by his extensive use of the original documents recording exactly what happened to him - documents that he was only recently given access to.
I read it after watching the BBC Omnibus documentary on Lemn Sissay and I’d advise anybody intending to read his book to watch the TV programme because it updates his story by showing his remarkable achievements as a poet,

A compelling and powerful memoir which reflects the resilience required to be ‘Other’ in a system that does not cater to you. Sissay’s beautiful poetry is interspersed throughout each chapter and the use of social workers’ case notes is very effective.

My Name Is Why is Lemn Sissay's poetic, heartbreaking, scathing look at the foster care system in the UK and how he was failed by it time and time again. Sissay's mother was an Ethiopian student who studying abroad at a university in the UK when she became pregnant. Due to circumstances beyond her control she was unable to care for him right away and he was put in temporary foster care. He could never be adopted though because she has refused to sign her rights away. So begins the memoir which e

If you can read this book and NOT get angry whilst doing so, then you’re a better person than me. My Name is Why is Lemn Sissay’s true story of his life in the English Care system. His Ethiopian mother handed her son into the care of Social Services whilst she finished her nursing course, only to have him permanently taken away and put in to long term foster care. Little Weirds is a book that was so good I was a bit sad to finish it. It’s a book that reminds you how beautiful life can be, but also how terrifying it can be, and how those two concepts coexist and dance together. It’s about embracing every little piece that makes you who you are. Jenny’s prose feels like a weird dream from childhood, or an old romantic film, or a trip abroad, where everything is new and exciting and odd and your heart feels on fire. I highly recommend giving it a read.

This book gave me tips on how to write poetry?

1. Write one long sentence.
2. Now divide this sentence in many parts (each part shall contain roughly 3-4 words).
3. Use one line to write each part of the above sentence.
4. Repeat the process till you've filled bunch of pages.
5. *Tada* You have a poem.

Beowulf is an Old English epic poem consisting of 3,182 alliterative lines. It is one of the most important works of Old English literature. The date of composition is a matter of contention among scholars; the only certain dating pertains to the manuscript, which was produced between 975 and 1025.

The author was an anonymous Anglo-Saxon poet, referred to by scholars as the "Beowulf poet".
